data.title: BreakpointEvent causes all other breakpoints in file to be cleared
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary

Steps to Reproduce:

1. User starts debugging a file which spawns a debug adapter
2. User clicks breakpoints in the gutter of that file
3. Something happens in the debug adapter causing a BreakpointEvent to be sent back to the debugger client
4. New breakpoint icon appears on the appropriate line, all other breakpoint icons disappear

I've tried this with `reason` set to `new` and `changed`, same result.

data.title: Add `when` context for to allow for "Maximize Editor Group and Hide Sidebar / Even Editor Group Widths" toggling
data.body:
Following on #8989, we have the ability to bind shortcuts for `maximizeEditor` and `evenEditorWidths` as a workaround for the fact that `Maximize Editor Group and Hide Sidebar` is not a toggle.

Would it be possible to get a context to allow the keyboard shortcut to effectively toggle between the two with the same keyboard shortcut?

e.g.

```
    {
        "key": "shift+cmd+enter",
        "command": "workbench.action.maximizeEditor",
        "when": "!editorGroupMaximized"
    },
    {
        "key": "shift+cmd+enter",
        "command": "workbench.action.evenEditorWidths",
        "when": "editorGroupMaximized"
    }
```

Aside if the difficulty in making `Maximize Editor Group and Hide Sidebar` a toggle is the "Hide Sidebar" bit, from a usability perspective, I think the showing or hiding of the sidebar could be left to the user in any case (like `Toggle Maximized Panel` for example).

Thanks for the consideration.

data.title: Version 1.11.1 causes blank screen on Mac
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

After updating to version 1.11.1, opening Visual Studio Code 2 only provides a blank screen (see attachment). Restarting application and OS doesn't help. Reinstall doesn't help either.

![screen shot 2017-04-07 at 10 35 33 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1669373/24780986/7bff700e-1b7f-11e7-9346-8ad758d0dcd2.png)

- **OS Version:** OSX 10.11.6

### Steps to Reproduce:

1. Update Visual Studio Code 2 to latest version (1.11.1)
2. Run the application
3. Only a blank window is displayed (no options or other screens are available)

Possible duplicate? https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24155

data.title: formatting issue when looking at settings defaults
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.1 (d9484d12b38879b7f4cdd1150efeb2fd2c1fbf39, 2017-04-06T13:58:12.954Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions: 
|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|aessoft-class-autocomplete|AESSoft|0.1.0|
|phpserver|brapifra|1.1.0|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|php-project|FrogTheFrog|2.0.2|
|composer|ikappas|0.5.0|
|path-autocomplete|ionutvmi|1.4.1|
|php-symbols|linyang95|2.1.0|
|phpmd|linyang95|1.1.4|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Open Visual Studio Code
2.  From the FILE menu choose PREFERENCES then sub menu item SETTINGS
3.  Setting window opens, with defaults on the left and overrides on the right.
4.  Find a long "default" setting category, such as "Composer Dependency Manager for PHP Configuration (2)"
5.  Notice sub items:

  // Is composer enabled.
  "composer.enabled": true,

  // Path to the composer executable.
  "composer.executablePath": null,

6.  Expand the divider bar between the default settings and the overrides window (user settings).
7.  When you can see the complete text on on line, then begin to SHRINK the divider bar forcing the text for  "Composer Dependency Manager for PHP Configuration (2)" to contract and wrap onto 2 or 3 lines.
8.  The text for main heading "Composer Dependency Manager for PHP Configuration (2)" will overlap the text for setting "composer.enabled": true, - making it difficult to read the setting.

![default settings before shrink](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26986675/24780487/f5b9b002-1af4-11e7-88c9-3196e72a4856.png)
![default settings after shrink - overlapping](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26986675/24780488/f602e0d8-1af4-11e7-936a-93f3aee46b8c.png)

WORK-AROUND:  Expanding the divider bar will alleviate this layout defect.

<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4
- British Keyboard Layout

Whenever I try to use shortcuts which use the § and ` keys, their values appear to be reversed.  The keys work correctly on every other app and everywhere else within VS Code; it's specifically when they're used as shortcuts.  The problem extends to when I try to rebind them as well:

To be clear, the 'key' value is the correct one and the 'UI' value is the incorrect one the shortcut recognises.

data.title: Can't find a C++ source file on ecryptfs home directory during debug process on Ubuntu.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.10 4.10.8 Generic Kernel.

Every time I tried to debug a C++ software with breakpoints, Code said it could not find the source code file and created a empty file at a strange place (/home/"myusername"/353254270354204234/"projectnameakamyprecious"/main.cpp). The debugging process worked; however, this issue made debugging process little tricky since I was not able to follow up with the debugger.

Code can open files without any problems, but whenever I use the debugger, Code opens a new file and sets step on the empty file.

I am referring to ecryptfs because that's what I am using, and I am thinking that the software [ecryptfs] is causing the problem.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install Ubuntu with ecryptfs (Home directory encryption).
2. Debug a C++ file with a breakpoint.
3. Notice that Code does not open the source file with breakpoints but a new one.

data.title: Cannot run build after upgrade
data.body:
Hello, I don't yet know my way around VSCode but I was using it to try some things out and ran into a problem. I was working with a project and it would build fine. At some point, VSCode and it told me that an update was available. I decided to install the update. After that, I can no longer run build because of the following error: Cannot read property 'config' of undefined

I took my project down to its simplest form and even created a new empty project with one simple file. When I hit ctrl-shift-b I get the cannot read property config error. Everything else seems to work and I can open the console and compile/build from there. I have looked for some sort of logging and I see nothing. 

I have tried removing all keyboard and workspace customization but I still get the error. Any idea what I need to do to fix this?

data.title: Suggestion: support file path completion in launch.json fields
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a new launch.json file in any debug adapter that has fields that should be file paths (ex: `program`).
2. Start editing this field

Result:
No completion is given

Suggestion:
Allow a debug adapter's schema to indicate that `string` fields are file paths, and if so, provide file system based completion help.

data.title: Allow overriding extension-based syntax highlighting, and specifying syntax used in unsaved files
data.body:
My apologies if this issue (or feature) already exists, but I looked through all search results for "syntax" and combed through the command palette before opening a new issue.

Basically, there are lots of times when I use my IDE of choice (VS Code these days, previously ST3) as a quick'n'dirty scratchpad.  Whether I'm copying a code snippet, a JSON payload, or a full script, I typically just double-click in the tab bar to open a new blank document, paste in the code, and then want to parse through it.  Using Sublime Text, it was easy to simply open the command palette, type "js", pick "set syntax: JavaScript", and I was good to go.  Once I was done perusing the contents, I could just close the tab, choose to leave the file unsaved, and I was back to a squeaky-clean workspace.

But with VS Code, it seems like there's no way to specify a syntax other than saving a file with a specific extension.  This means that my previously smooth workflow now has the added requirements of saving the file (that I have no intention of keeping) to disk somewhere, then remembering to go and delete it after I'm done looking through it.

I don't think there's any need to get fancy, like trying to remember syntax overrides on specific files - I'd say that the current behavior of applying the associated syntax highlighting whenever the file is opened is fine. I'd just like to be able to override the automatically-applied syntax after opening, and to be able to apply a syntax to a "new file" without having to save it.
